questions.question: 1. The uniformity coefficient (C<sub>u</sub>) of soil is ____.

explanations.a: This is impossible as when we apply this condition on the formula D<sub>60</sub> / D<sub>10</sub>, it implies that D<sub>60</sub> < D<sub>10</sub>, i.e, 60% of the soil particles are finer for a smaller size than the size for which 10% of the particles are finer which is not possible.
explanations.b: While this is possible (as D<sub>60</sub> can equal D<sub>10</sub>), it is not the only possibility and does not account for a large number of cases where C<sub>u</sub> is not 1.
explanations.c: While this is possible (as D<sub>60</sub> can be greater than D<sub>10</sub>), it is not the only possibility and does not account for a specific corner case.
explanations.d: This is the right relation as D<sub>60</sub> can be greater than or equal to D<sub>10</sub>.

questions.question: 2. Sieve analysis is used when the size of particles is ____.

explanations.a: It is possible to design sieves for sizes > 75 micron and this method helps when the particles have varying sizes.
explanations.b: It is difficult to design sieves for sizes smaller than 75 micron and hence turns out to be ineffective in this case.
explanations.c: When most/all of the particles have the same size, sieve analysis is ineffective.
explanations.d: When most/all of the particles have the same size, sieve analysis is ineffective.

questions.question: 3. For coarse grained soil, the particle size D<sub>10</sub> is sometimes called as ____.

explanations.a: D<sub>10</sub> size is termed as effective particle size as it means that only 10% particles are finer than that size and 90% are coarser.
explanations.b: This is an incorrect name and is counter intuitive for the definition of D<sub>10</sub>.
explanations.c: D<sub>10</sub> size isn't called by both of the above names simultaneously, i.e, it is called either one or none, but not both.
explanations.d: One of the other options contains the correct name for D<sub>10</sub> particle size.

questions.question: 4. A soil having a uniformity coefficient smaller than about 2 is considered uniformly graded.

explanations.a: The uniformity coefficient (C<sub>u</sub>) value is less than 4 for poorly/uniformly graded soil, more than 4 for well graded gravel and more than 6 for well graded sand. Higher value of C<sub>u</sub> indicates that the soil mass consists of soil particles with different size ranges.

Higher value of C<sub>u</sub> indicates that the soil mass consists of soil particles with different size ranges.
